awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides partial support to help defray the expenses of participants in the 2020 East Coast Operator Algebra Symposium (ECOAS), which will be held on the University of Virginia campus in Charlottesville, Virginia, October 17-18, 2020. The symposium expects to host between 40-60 participants, including many graduate students and postdocs. This will be the eighteenth annual meeting in the East Coast Operator Algebra Symposium series. 

The conference focuses on operator algebras (C* and von Neumann algebras) and non-commutative geometry. This year we are particularly focusing on connections to quantum information theory, quantum algebra, conformal field theory, unitary representation theory, deformation/rigidity theory, and C*-classification. The ECOAS enables participants to become acquainted with the modern developments in operator algebras, non-commutative geometry, and neighboring disciplines.  A major goal is to highlight the work of early-career researchers and facilitate them networking with other junior as well as senior researchers. More information can be found at the conference website: https://sites.google.com/view/ecoas2020uva/home?authuser=2.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this grant was to defray costs for a series of confernces "East Coast Operator Algebras Symposium" hosted at Michigan State University in 2023 and Purdue University in 2024.

 

The intellectual merit of these conferences is encapsulated by the series of talks- here researchers in the field present their current results in operator algebras and adjacent fields. Operator algebras is subdiscipline of mathematics that forms the basis for quantum mechanics. It also has applications to statistical mechanics and knot theory. Talks at conferences like these are one of the primary ways in which researchers in the field present their results to the public and it one of the major avenues in which researchers in the field gain exposure to the significant and important results in the subject.

 

This particular series of conferences is aimed at early-career researchers, especially graduate students. The funds from this grant were primarily aimed at reimbursing their travel and lodging. Participation and attendance in conferences like these are vital to the long-term success of early-career researchers (especially graduate students), as it provides them not only the exposure to important topics alluded to above, but also gives them an opportunity to form career connections which frequently turn into collaboration or mentorship. These conferences form the basis for training that ultimately turns newcomers in the field into the next generation of experts.
